Household Rainwater Collection: Why, What and How. (and a good chance of having a short presentation by Wendy Garland from Maine DEP).

Get ready for the mud season by harvesting water for use in irrigation and other activities. We will discuss rain barrels, cisterns and possibly a preliminary talk about ponds in your residential landscape (in anticipation of a pond workshop in the Spring).

Note: This is going to be held at Pam's house - about 25 minutes from the Marginal Way Park & Ride. ** I am opening up a CARPOOLING thread on the message board for people to connect on rides to Pam's House**
http://www.google.com...

I'm searching for a good data source on local rainwater collection, but it looks like Portland receives an average of about 46 inches of precipitation each year. If you lived in a house that had 20 ft x 30 ft footprint (600 square feet) and harvested water from your roof, that means ...

46 inches rainfall x 1/12th foot per inch = 3.83 feet rainfall
3.83 feet rainfall x 600 square foot roof = 2300 cubic feet of water
2300 cubic feet x 7.5 gal per cubic foot = 17,250 gallons of potential collection per year!

Resources will be provided on where to purchase and/or how to make rainwater collections systems.

To avoid carb-loading for our POTLUCK, let's breakdown the list a bit:
Last name starting with A-G bring bread or beverage
Last name starting with H-M bring main or side dish to share
Last name starting with N-S bring salad or veg or dessert
Last name starting with T-Z bring whatever you want
We'll rotate this list each month so you won't be stuck in a rut:)
